awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Quantitative Analysis of Liposome Deformation at Nanoscale Using Resistive Pulse Sensing in Solid State Nanopores
awd_abstract_narration:
Tiny lipid sacs, called liposomes, play a crucial role in living cells as means to store and transport material in and out of the cell. The key task of liposomes (storage and delivery to targets) requires them to be flexible enough to merge with target membranes in order to deliver their cargos, and yet to have sufficient structural stability to maintain integrity without rupturing and losing the stored material in the naturally dynamic biological environments.  Therefore,  understanding the mechanics of liposomes is of great interest to both fundamental and applied scientists who are developing artificial, biomimetic liposomes as targeted drug/gene delivery systems for better therapeutics. A major challenge however, is the lack of efficient engineering tools to probe the mechanical flexibility of the sub-cellular, nanoscale liposomes. The research addresses this need by developing a novel method based on nanopore technology that uses electric fields to deform liposomes and electrical measurements to characterize their shape. The overall goal is to characterize the mechanical flexibility of nano-liposomes with the ultimate goal to establish a method to study mechanical properties of nanoscale objects such as  viruses and other biological samples at cellular/molecular level.

This project will advance the engineering tools for mechanical characterization of soft biological materials at the micro/nanoscale. The technology uses nanopore resistive pulse sensing to detect membrane deformation. As liposomes translocate through a nanopore, they experience strong electric stresses and physical confinement, which cause deformation. In this project, liposome shapes will be inferred from ionic current blockade, i.e., the sharp change (pulse) in ohmic resistance when a liposome is present in the pore. A theoretical model for liposome deformation in the nanopore will be developed to yield membrane mechanical properties. The method will enable both high-throughput and single-particle resolution because  (1) thousands of liposomes pass through the nanopore and a resistive pulse will be recorded for each individual one, and (2) thousands of measurements on a single liposome can be made by alternating the applied electric field direction to drive back-and-forth translocation. In broader terms, this method will enable studying mechanobiology at novel unprecedented scales, which is single-virus and single-particle level.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

The purpose of this project was to demonstrate the ability of solid-state nanopores to collect the resistive spikes of three different samples and conducted statistical analyses which gave us more insight into the mechanical properties of these liposomes. We observed a difference in resistive pulse characteristics between soft liposomes, especially at different voltages. Furthermore, analyzing the data with machine learning is a step forward and provides thorough novel validation of classifying between each liposome type with accuracy by characterizing each type on segments of each experimental resistive-pulse signal into hundreds of data and running the model for tens of data sets from each experiment. For the transformed data results, the mean accuracy of the network remained above 85% for each sample type, regardless of the voltage bias or time frame.

100%DOPC, 50%DOPC50%Peo-b-pbd and 50%POPC/50%Cholesterol liposomes were experimentally tested under different applied voltages (e.g. -500mV, -400mV, -300mV, -200mV). Our first set of experiments was conducted with relatively smaller pore diameter (~260-280nm) for each type of liposome. To summarize, the key outcomes as follows:

  • Translocation frequency increases when increasing the voltage.
  • Relative current blockade (dI/Io) values are all positively skewed at all applied voltages. This skewness maybe is a result of sample aggregation.
  • We saw more uniform current drops values resulting in a tight population distribution. In some samples, we saw tight population distribution as compared to others.
  • Population cluster shifts with the voltage and we observed higher current drops (dI) at -500mV compared to -200mV. We observe well separated and very distinct population clusters for the 3 samples.

Notable achievements were:

●       Data collection of electrical signals from translocation events of three different types of liposomes.

  • Statistical analysis of parameters (e.g., translocation time, relative current blockade (dI/Io).
  • Deep learning algorithm that provides validation and identification of each liposome’s type with deep accuracy by relying on their distinct features in the transformed data.

 


Last Modified: 09/17/2021
Modified by: Minjun Kim

Image
  • Soft nanoparticle is translocating through a nanopore for measuring its defomability.
    MinJun Kim
    Copyrighted
    Minjun Kim
    Nanopore Force Spectroscopy
